pages.text: As you have now seen, combining 2 black or white chickens gives a chick of the same color. By combining black and white chickens, you get a gray chicken. But if you combine 2 gray chickens, you can get black, white and gray chickens.
Why is this happening? How can 2 gray chickens give you a black or a white one?

Every chicken has chromosomes, which contain the code for the characteristics of the chicken, in this case the color of the chicken. There are two copies of each chromosome. One comes from the father and the other from the mother. Those chromosomes contain the genes that determine the color of the chicken. For the black and white chickens each have the same chromosome twice. Either two times a chromosome with the black gene or two times a chromosome with the white gene. The gray chickens have both a chromosome with a black and one with a white gene.
Gray chickens can give you black, white and gray chickens. Gray chickens can do this because they have both types of genes.
The probability of a chick getting a certain color can be visually represented using the 'Punnett Square'.
So, there is 50% chance to get a gray chick, and 25% chance of getting either a white or black chick. How do these numbers compare to your findings in Experiment 2?
